title: VARIABILITY OF A VESTIGIAL STRUCTURE: FIRST METACARPAL IN COLOBUS GUEREZA AND ATELES GEOFFROY]
abstract: A tenet of evolutionary theory is that, under conditions of stabilizing selection, phenotypic variability is inversely related to selection intensity. Correspondingly, a nonfunctional, vestigial structure is expected to be highly variable relative to its functional homologue. This study tests the hypothesis that species with a vestigial pollex, Colobus guereza and Ateles geoffroyi, have a first metacarpal whose length is both highly variable relative to, and poorly correlated with, the lengths of the other metapodials. The results are consistent with the hypothesis, though this combination of traits is also found in Presbytis rubicunda and Presbytis cristata. The latter two species have functional, albeit miniature, pollices, This study also demonstrates a general, inverse relationship among anthropoid primates between relative length of the first metapodial and its relative variability, These results suggest that elevated variability accompanies structural reduction.

abstract.text: A tenet of evolutionary theory is that, under conditions of stabilizing selection, phenotypic variability is inversely related to selection intensity. Correspondingly, a nonfunctional, vestigial structure is expected to be highly variable relative to its functional homologue. This study tests the hypothesis that species with a vestigial pollex, Colobus guereza and Ateles geoffroyi, have a first metacarpal whose length is both highly variable relative to, and poorly correlated with, the lengths of the other metapodials. The results are consistent with the hypothesis, though this combination of traits is also found in Presbytis rubicunda and Presbytis cristata. The latter two species have functional, albeit miniature, pollices, This study also demonstrates a general, inverse relationship among anthropoid primates between relative length of the first metapodial and its relative variability, These results suggest that elevated variability accompanies structural reduction.

body_text.text: The evolutionary and developmental bases of phenotypic variation within species have been the subject of numerous theoretical and empirical studies. This study addresses the issue of whether a vestigial structure is phenotypically more variable than its functional homologue.

Biologists have long considered vestigial structures to be highly variable. For example, Darwin (1964, p. 149) remarked that "rudimentary parts ... are apt to be highly variable." Moreover, Simpson (1944, p. 39) averred that "it is so commonly true that degenerating structures are highly variable that this may be advanced as an empirical evolutionary generalization." However, previous reports of the high variability of vestigial structures are typically of two kinds. First, the researcher refers to the inconstant presence, asymmetrical appearance, or occasional full development of the vestige within a species (Prentiss 1906; Schultz 1926b; Essex 1927; Fraser 1951; Smith 1956; Emerson 1961; Van der Merwe 1985b; Blouw and Boyd 1992) . Second, the researcher presents an interspecific comparison illustrating differences in the extent of structural reduction (Essex 1927; Stokely 1947; Emerson 1961; Renous et al. 1991) . Rarely do these reports assess quantitatively the magnitude of variation of a vestigial structure. While some researchers present a frequency distribution or a range of variation (Smith 1956; George and Brown 1968; Jouffroy and Lessertisseur 1977; Van der Merwe 1985b) , seldom is the variance reported (but see Schultz 1926a; Hosokawa 1951; Seibt and Wickler 1985; Van der Merwe 1985a; Jouffroy et al. 1993 ). This study compares quantitatively the variability of a rudimentary structure with that of its functional homologue among closely related species of anthropoid primates (i.e., apes and monkeys).

Theoretically, a nonfunctional, vestigial structure should be phenotypically more variable than its functional homologue. A tenet of evolutionary theory is that, within a species, phenotypic (and genetic) variability is inversely related to the intensity of stabilizing selection (Schmalhausen 1949; Yablokov 1974; Johnson 1976; Endler 1986; Mettler et al. 1988) . As a nonfunctional structure is subject to relaxed selection pressure relative to its functional homologue, the for-mer is expected to be phenotypically more variable than the latter. Guthrie (1965) , however, suggested that a vestigial structure is, in essence, an evolving character and, thereby, subject to directional selection. Guthrie (1965) and Yablokov (1974) argued that structures under directional selection exhibit high phenotypic variability (but see Bader 1955; Johnson 1976; Lande and Arnold 1983) . Regardless of the mode of selection, the consensus is that a vestigial structure is expected to be highly variable.

Researchers differ in the definition of vestigiality (Yablokov 1974; Junker 1990 ). Some researchers equate vestigiality with nonfunctionality (Mason 1928; Simpson 1944; Van Valen 1960; Prout 1964; Scadding 1981 Scadding , 1982 Boucher 1986; Grant 1991) , and several ideas have been advanced to explain the mechanism for structural reduction consequent to loss of function (Huxley 1932; De Beer 1958; Brace 1963; Prout 1964; Regal 1977) . However, ascertainment of functional inutility can be problematic (Van Valen 1960; Scadding 1981) , and functional significance has been attributed to some vestigial structures (Radinsky 1963; Naylor 1982) . Other researchers define vestigiality in terms of morphological criteria, such as miniature size and variable presence (Heston 1951; Radinsky 1963; Van der Merwe 1985a,b ; also see citations in Yablokov 1974; Junker 1990 ). This study analyzes the first metacarpal (MCl) bone of the vestigial pollex in two species of monkeys.

Primates are characterized by a generalized pentadactyl hand and foot (Martin 1990; Jouffroy et al. 1993) , in which the pollex consists of a metacarpal and two phalanges. Three genera, however, have a vestigial pollex: Colobus (the blackand-white colobus monkey of Africa, from Senegal to Ethiopia and from Angola to Tanzania); Ateles (the spider monkey of Central and South America, from southern Mexico to central Bolivia and Brazil); and Brachyteles (the woolly spider monkey of South America, from southeastern Brazil) (Wolfheim 1983) . (As only specimens of Colobus and Ateles were available for this study, further discussion will be lim-ited to these genera.) In Colobus and Ateles, the pollex is only a nubbin that projects from the palm, and the rudimentary pollex may be asymmetrical in development, being visibly evident on only one of the hands (Pocock 1925a,b; Schultz 1926b; Mildo 1934; Jouffroy and Lessertisseur 1977; Morbeck 1979; Rosenberger and Strier 1989) . The pollex of Colobus and Ateles consists of a small MC1 and a (variably present) minute proximal phalanx; Colobus occasionally has a tiny distal phalanx (Schultz 1924; Straus 1942; Jouffroy and Lessertisseur 1977; Jouffroy et al. 1993) . The pollical musculature is generally rudimentary, but variable in development (Straus 1942 (Straus , 1949 Jouffroy and Lessertisseur 1960; Turnquist 1983) .

In primates, the pollex is used primarily in prehension, which includes both "power" and "precision" grips (Napier 1960) . In a power grip, the "object is held as in a clamp between the flexed fingers and the palm, counter pressure being applied by the adducted thumb" (Napier 1960, p. 648) . As a result of Colobus' and Ateles' rudimentary pollex, their power grip is limited to digits two through five, and, therefore, is a hook grip (Napier and Napier 1967) . However, apes also routinely use only these four digits in a power grip because these digits are disproportionately long relative to the pollex (Napier 1960; Tuttle 1969 Tuttle , 1972 Preuschoft et al. 1993) .

In a precision grip, the "object is gripped between the palmar aspect of the terminal phalanx of the finger or fingers and the thumb" (Napier 1960, p. 648) . Based on this definition, an opposable pollex is requisite for a precision grip. Although the pollex is opposable in catarrhines (i.e., monkeys of the Old World and apes), only some catarrhines can hold an object between the terminal digital phalanges. The reason is that there are interspecific differences in the relative lengths of the pollex and the other digits. For catarrhines with a short pollex, the object may be clasped between the pollex and the side of the second digit (Napier 1960; Bishop 1964 ; but see Christel 1993) . In platyrrhines (i.e., monkeys of the New World), the pollex is pseudo-opposable (Bishop 1964; Napier and Napier 1967) . Platyrrhines perform a modified precision grip by either flexing the pollex around the object or holding the object with a scissorslike action between two adducted digits, such as the pollex and the second digit or the second and third digits (Erikson 1963; Bishop 1964; Napier and Napier 1967) .

Pollical vestigiality has not altogether compromised Ateles' precision grip because it can use its second and third digits for this action, as do other platyrrhines (Bishop 1964) . Free-ranging Colobus guereza, however, infrequently uses its vestigial pollex in a precision grip (Morbeck 1979) , though captive Colobus polykomos has been observed manipulating objects by pressing its second digit against the pollical stub (Bishop 1964) . In general, however, the rudimentary pollex in Colobus and Ateles obviates its use in prehension.

The ultimate cause for pollical reduction probably differs between Colobus and Ateles. Although the locomotor repertoire of Ateles is varied (Mittermeier and Fleagle 1976; Mittermeier 1978; Fontaine 1990 ), Stern and Oxnard (1973) and Rosenberger and Strier (1989) argued that its rudimentary pollex enhances the hook grip used in brachiation. Straus (1942 Straus ( , 1949 argued that, in general, pollical reduction is functionally advantageous in brachiation. However, Hylobates (i.e., the gibbon) is also a brachiator, and its pollex, though short relative to the other digits, is not a functionless vestige (Tuttle 1969 (Tuttle , 1972 . In contrast with Ateles, Colobus is primarily an arboreal quadruped and leaper (Mittermeier and Fleagle 1976; Morbeck 1977 Morbeck ,1979 Rose 1978) . Colobus frequently leaps from tree to tree, and pollical reduction may facilitate the grasping of branches in their forelimb-first landings (Stern and Oxnard 1973; Morbeck 1979) .

As only Colobus, Ateles, and Brachyteles have a rudimentary, nonfunctional pollex among anthropoids, and as the former two genera are distantly related phylogenetically (e.g., they are classified in different infraorders within Primates-Catarrhini and Platyrrhini), this shared trait represents convergent evolution. Therefore, demonstration that MC1 is highly variable in both Colobus and Ateles would provide independent and strong support for the thesis that elevated variability accompanies vestigiality. Specifically, this study compares C. guereza and Ateles geoffroyi with ten other species of anthropoids, and tests the hypothesis that in the former two species the length of MC 1 is both highly variable relative to, and poorly correlated with, the lengths of metacarpals two through five (MC2-5). Metatarsals are also included in the analysis to which the results for the metacarpals are compared.

This study analyzed metacarpals and metatarsals in 12 species of anthropoid primates: A. geoffroyi (spider monkey), Alouatta palliata (mantled howler monkey), and Lagothrix lagotricha (common woolly monkey) of the subfamily Atelinae; C. guereza (guereza black-and-white colobus monkey), Presbytis rubicunda (maroon leaf monkey), and Presbytis cristata (silvered leaf monkey) of the subfamily Colobinae; Papio cynocephalus (yellow baboon), Cercopithecus aethiops (vervet monkey), and Macaca fascicularis (crab-eating macaque monkey) of the subfamily Cercopithecinae; and Pan troglodytes (common chimpanzee), Pongo pygmaeus (orangutan), and Hylobates lar (white-handed gibbon) of the superfamily Hominoidea. Specimens were included in the study only if all five metacarpals (MCl-5) and/or all five metatarsals (MTl-5) were present and if the epiphyses were fused. Pathological bones were not analyzed. Museum records were used to identify a specimen's species and sex, as well as whether it had been wild-caught or maintained in captivity. Table 1 presents the summary information on sample composition. Harris et al. (1992) reported that in adult humans there is a shortening of metacarpal length with advancing age. As age at death of the specimens in this study was unknown, there could be no control for differences among the samples in age composition.

Maximum length between the proximal and distal joint surfaces was measured on each metapodial; no adjustment was made for curvature of the metapodial shaft. Measurements were taken using sliding calipers, and were recorded to the nearest 0.1 mm. For some specimens, only the metapodials of one hand or foot were available. When both the right and left metapodials were available, their mean was used in the analysis.

To determine the level of precision in measuring metapodial length, the metapodials from one hand and foot of 20 P. cynocephalus specimens were remeasured four years after the original set of measurements was taken. The results showed the level of precision to be high. The mean absolute difference between the original and repeat measurements ranged from zero for MC5 to 0.11 mm (SD = 0.10) for MT5. Relative to metapodial length, the mean absolute difference between the two sets of measurements ranged from zero for MC5 to 0.16% (SD = 0.15) for MT5. For the combined sample of 200 metapodials, the mean absolute difference between the original and repeat measurements was 0.02 mm (SD = 0.06), and the mean absolute difference relative to metapodiallength was 0.04% (SD = 0.09).

SPSSPC+ version 5.0 was used for the statistical analyses. With the exception of the evaluation of mensuration error (see above), the data were transformed to their natural logarithms for the analyses. The samples consisted of both sexes and of wild-caught and captive specimens. As some samples were small in size and others showed a significant difference from a normal distribution (results of the one-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for an intrinsic hypothesis not presented), the median and the average median variation (AMV) (Schultz 1985) AMV = 1In~?~dlnX; -median(lnX;)I,

(1) were used as the summary statistics of central tendency and dispersion, respectively. AMV is less influenced by a nonnormal sample distribution than are other such measures of dispersion, such as the coefficient of variation (Sokal and Braumann 1980; Schultz 1985) .

Assessment of sample composition.-The Mann-Whitney test was used to compare wild-caught and captive specimens, as well as males and females, within each species for differences in the absolute and proportionate lengths of their metapodials. A two-tailed test of significance (P :s; 0.05) was applied. These comparisons served to evaluate the appropriateness of combining all specimens within a species into a single sample for the analysis of metapodial variability.

In the comparison of absolute metapodiallength, the magnitude of sexual dimorphism was computed for each metapodial in each species: sexual dimorphism = In(male median/female medianjrz) Although there are "statistical difficulties associated with ratios ... because X/Y is not a linear function of X and Y ... [t] he difficulties disappear if one uses logarithms because 10g(X/Y) = log X -log Y, and this is a linear function of log X and log Y" (Hills 1978, p. 61) . To compare proportionate metapodial lengths between wild-caught and captive specimens and between males and females, the length of one metapodial relative to that of another metapodial was calculated for all 10 combinations of metacarpals (e.g., In [MC 11 MC2] , In[MC1IMC3], ... and In[MC4/MC5]) and the corresponding combinations of metatarsals. As there is a high correlation among the metapodials in their lengths (see Results), assessment of a difference between males and females, for example, in proportionate metapodial length was based on a "pattern" of significant differences. This study considered there to be a pattern of significant differences for a particular metapodial if three of the four Mann-Whitney tests involving that metapodial (e.g., the four combinations for MCI were MC1:MC2, MC1:MC3, MC1:MC4, and MC1: MC5) were significant.

Association between length and variability of a metapodial.-For each metapodial, the median length and AMV were computed for each sex in each species. Of the 24 potential samples (i.e., two sexes in each of 12 species), 19 samples had at least eight specimens and were, therefore, included in the analysis (see below for discussion of sample size and use of AMV). For each metapodial, Spearman's rank-order correlation coefficient was calculated between the median length and AMV. As some researchers have observed an inverse relationship between size of a structure and its variability (Bader and Hall 1959; Yablokov 1974; Rohlf et al. 1983 ), a one-tailed test of significance (P :s; 0.05) was applied.

Association between sexual dimorphism and variability of a metapodial.-Using a pooled-sex sample, the magnitude of sexual dimorphism and AMV were computed for each metapodial in each species. Spearman's correlation coefficient was calculated between these variables for each metapodial in the sample of 12 species. The expectation was that AMV for a pooled-sex sample would be positively related to the magnitude of sexual dimorphism in metapodial length; therefore, a one-tailed test of significance (P -s 0.05) was applied.

Variability among metapodials: intraspecific analysis.-Using a pooled-sex sample within each species, Levene's test (using a one-way ANOVA or, if appropriate, the Kruskal-Wallis test) was used to determine if there was a significant difference among the metapodials in their AMVs. Although there is a plethora of statistical tests for analyzing variance (Conover et al. 1981 ), Levene's test is both robust and powerful under varying shapes of sample distributions and sample sizes (Brown and Forsythe 1974; Van Valen 1978; Conover et al. 1981; Schultz 1983 Schultz , 1985 ; but see Martin and Games 1977) . However, Van Valen (1978, p. 34) has noted that "Levene's test isn't quite a test of equality of variances. It is, strictly speaking, a joint test of all the even moments of the distributions: variance, kurtosis, etc. However, the effect of the variance predominates." For samples with fewer than eight specimens, Schultz (1985) recommended against the use of Levene's test, and this recommendation was followed in the present study.

Association between length and variability of first metapodials: interspecific analysis.-The median lengths and AMVs of the first metapodials (MPls) were compared among the 12 species. As several variables may influence the magnitude of AMV (e.g., sample composition and sexual dimorphism), the relative average median variation (RAMV) and relative median length (RML) ofMPls were used in the analysis. Using MCI as the example (and where L is length):
EQUATION

For the sample of 12 species, Spearman's correlation coefficient was calculated between RAMV and RML of MPls. As some researchers have noted an inverse relationship between size of a structure and its variability (Bader and Hall 1959; Yablokov 1974; Rohlf et al. 1983 ), a one-tailed test of significance (P -s 0.05) was applied.

Association among metapodials in their lengths.-Mean correlation coefficients were computed (i.e., average of Spearman's coefficients [Siegel and Castellan 1988] ) between MPI and its corresponding metapodials two through five (MP2-5), and among all combinations for MC2-5 and MT2-5. Fisher's z-transformation was not used in the computation of the mean correlation coefficients as the overwhelming majority of Spearman's coefficients were greater than 0.9 (Zar 1984) .

Assessment of sample composition.-Wild-caught and captive specimens, and males and females, were compared for differences in the absolute and proportionate lengths of their metapodials. Of the seven species with both wild-caught and captive specimens (Table I) , only four had sufficient sample sizes to evaluate by the Mann-Whitney test: both sexes in C. guereza (for females, only the metacarpals could be evaluated) and C. aethiops, and females only in A. geoffroyi and P. pygmaeus. The results (not presented) show that only C. guereza females evidence a significant difference in absolute metapodial length between wild-caught and captive specimens--captive females have longer MC2 and MC4-5 than the wild-caught females. Furthermore, only C. aethiops males show a pattern of significant difference in proportionate metapodiallength (for MTI, results not presented) between wild-caught and captive specimens. Collectively, these results suggest that wild-caught and captive specimens are generally similar in the absolute and proportionate lengths of their metapodials. Therefore, both types of specimens were pooled into a single sample for subsequent analysis. However, results on metapodial variability for C. guereza and C. aethiops will be evaluated in light of the significant differences noted above. Table 2 reports the magnitude of sexual dimorphism in absolute metapodial length and the probability level based on the Mann-Whitney test. A number of species show significant sexual dimorphism in metapodial length, with males being uniformly larger than females. In terms of proportionate metapodial length, however, only C. guereza (MCI) and P. cristata (MCI-2) show a pattern of significant difference between the sexes (results not presented). These results show that, within a species, males and females are generally similar in the proportionate lengths of their metapodials. Therefore, both sexes were pooled into a single sample for further analysis. However, the effect of the sexual differences noted above on AMV of the pooled-sex sample will be discussed.

Association between length and variability of a metapodial.- Table 3 shows that the correlation coefficients between median length and AMV are low and nonsignificantly different from zero for all metapodials.

Association between sexual dimorphism and variability of a metapodial.-Pooled-sex samples are used in the analysis. As the range of variation is logically expected to be larger with an increase in sexual dimorphism, the hypothesis is that there is a positive relationship between the absolute value of the magnitude of sexual dimorphism (Table 2) and AMV (Table 5). The results (Table 4) show that the correlation coefficients range from 0.68 (MTI) to 0.86 (MC3); all coefficients are significantly different from zero.

Variability among metapodials: intraspecific analysis.-Table 5 presents the summary statistics for AMV and median length for the metapodials in each species. The results of Levene's test (not presented) show that there are no significant differences among AMVs within any of the species.

Association between length and variability of first metapodials: interspecific analysis.-As the magnitude of sexual dimorphism is a direct correlate with AMV (Table 4) (Table 2 ) and average median variation (Table 5 ) of metapodials (one-tailed test of significance). Interspecific analysis using pooled-sex samples (n = 12). Abbreviations used: MC, metacarpal; MT, metatarsal. that A. geoffroyi and C. guereza have the highest RAMV for MC1, 1.61 and 1.47, respectively. A. palliata has the highest RAMV for MTl, 1.11.

Spearman's correlation coefficient between RAMV and RML of the combined sample of MPls (n = 24, Table 6 ) is -0.55 (P = 0.003). The correlation coefficient is significantly different from zero; a one-tailed test of significance was used.

Association among metapodials in their lengths.- Table 7 shows that the mean correlation coefficient for MPI ranges from 0.23 for MCI in A. geoffroyi to 0.96 for MTl in C. aethiops. The mean correlation coefficient for MCI in C. guereza is 0.55, which is the third lowest value. The mean correlation coefficients for MP2-5 range from 0.82 for both MC2-5 and MT2-5 in A. geoffroyi to 0.99 for MT2-5 in C.

Table 7 also reports the absolute difference in the mean correlation coefficients between MCI and MTI and between MC2-5 and MT2-5. The difference between the mean coefficients of MCI and MTI is high for A. geoffroyi (0.45), P. rubicunda (0.24), P. cristata (0.23), and C. guereza (0.22), whereas this difference is low for the other eight species (range is from zero for H. lar to 0.08 for P. cynocephalus). Moreover, for all species the difference is low between the mean coefficients for MC2-5 and MT2-5 (range is from zero TABLE 3. Spearman's correlation coefficients (r s ) between~dian length and average median variation of metapodials (one-tailed test of significance; ns P > 0.05). Interspecific analysis using sex-specific samples (n = 19; five samples had fewer than eight specimens and were not included in the analysis: male A. geoffroyi, female A. palliata, female P. cynocephalus, and both sexes of L. lagotricha [ Table 1]

This study tests the hypothesis that species with a vestigial pollex, C. guereza and A. geoffroyi, have MC 1 whose length is both highly variable relative to, and poorly correlated with, the lengths of MC2-5. The results support this hypothesis. However, this combination of traits is not unique to C. guereza and A. geoffroyi. Both P. rubicunda and P. cristata also have MCI that is both highly variable and poorly correlated in length relative to MC2-5. In contrast with C. guereza and A. geoffroyi, both species of Presbytis have two pollical phalanges, albeit their pollices are short relative to the other digits of the hand (Schultz 1986; Jouffroy et al. 1993 ). This TABLE 7. Spearman's mean correlation coefficients (r s ) forthe first metapodial (MPl) and for metapodials two through five (MP2-5). Intraspecific sample sizes for metacarpals and metatarsals are shown in Table 5 . MCI and MTI refer to the mean correlation coefficient between MPI and its corresponding MP2-5. (For MCl, the combinations are MCl:MC2, MCl:MC3, MCl:MC4, and MCl:MC5.) MC2-5 and MT2-5 refer to the mean correlation coefficient among MP2-5. (For MC2-5, the combinations are MC2:MC3, MC2:MC4, MC2:MC5, MC3:MC4, MC3:MC5, and MC4:MC5.) study also demonstrates an inverse relationship among anthropoids between RAMV and RML of MP1. The high variability of MCI in C. guereza, A. geoffroyi, P. rubicunda, and P. cristata is seen in the interspecific comparison of RAMV. Of the 24 RAMVs, the four highest values are for MCI in the abovementioned species: A. geoffroyi (1.61), C. guereza (1.47), P. cristata (1.41), and P. rubicunda (1.34) ( Table 6 ). Only one of the remaining 20 RAMVs is greater than 1.15: 1.17 for MCI in P. troglodytes. However, the assertion that MC1 in C. guereza, A. geoffroyi, P. rubicunda, and P. cristata is highly variable relative to the other metapodials is not unequivocal for two reasons. First, in none of the species in this study is AMV of MC 1 statistically significantly different from AMVs of the other metapodials. Second, RAMV is computed from summary statistics and, therefore, cannot be tested to determine if the interspecific heterogeneity is statistically significant.

The low correlation between MC1 and MC2-5 for C. guereza, A. geoffroyi, P. rubicunda, and P. cristata is seen in the interspecific comparison of the mean correlation coefficients. Among the 12 species, A. geoffroyi has the lowest mean correlation coefficient for MC1 (r s = 0.23), followed in order by P. rubicunda (rs = 0.42), C. guereza (r s = 0.55), and P. cristata and A. palliata (r s = 0.67 for both species) ( Table  7) . The low correlation between MC1 and MC2-5 is also illustrated in the absolute difference between the mean correlations of corresponding segments of the hand and foot. The difference between the mean correlations for MC2-5 and MT2-5 is nominal within each species; the range is from zero to 0.05 (Table 7) . In contrast, the difference between the mean correlations for MC 1 and MTl is high in A. geoffroyi (0.45), P. rubicunda (0.24), P. cristata (0.23), and C. guereza (0.22); the range for the other eight species is from zero to 0.08 . Therefore, the four species that show the highest RAMV of MC 1 also show the lowest correlation of MC 1 with MC2-5. These species have vestigial (c. guereza and A. geoffroyi) or miniature (P. rubicunda and P. cristata) pollices. (Lande [1978] has noted that miniaturization of a structure precedes its loss.) Before addressing the biological implications of these results, two alternative explanations are evaluated.

Sample composition.-The species in this study differ in the numbers of males and females and of wild-caught and captive specimens in their samples (Table 1) . However, this difference cannot explain the interspecific heterogeneity in RAMV of MP1. With the exception of MTl in C. aethiops males, wild-caught and captive specimens are similar in the proportionate lengths of their metapodials. Moreover, with the exception ofMCl in C. guereza and MCl-2 in P. cristata, males and females also are similar in the proportionate lengths of their metapodials. Therefore, though there may be a difference between the sexes or between wild-caught and captive specimens in the absolute length of their metapodials, the similarity in their proportionate lengths means that, when all specimens within a species are pooled into a single sample, an increase in AMV of one metapodial will be accompanied by a corresponding increase in AMV of the other metapodials. Consequently, regardless of sample composition, RAMV is analytically comparable among the species.

For the three species mentioned above that demonstrate a difference in proportionate metapodial length, the effect on AMV and RAMV of the pooled-sex sample depends on the magnitude of dimorphism in metapodial length. This study shows that there is a positive relationship between the magnitude of (sexual) dimorphism and AMV (Table 4 ). For C. aethiops, captive males have nonsignificantly longer metatarsals than wild-caught males, with the magnitude of dimorphism being the highest for MT1. Thus, the expectation is that AMV for MTl would be greater than that for MT2-5; accordingly, RAMV of MTl would be greater than 1.00. This effect, however, is evidently modest as RAMV of MTI in the pooled-sex sample of C. aethiops is 1.03 (Table 6 ).

For C. guereza, the sexes are nonsignificantly different in the absolute length of MC1, whereas they are significantly dimorphic for MC2-5 (Table 2) . Therefore, the expectation is that AMV of MCI would be less than that for MC2-5; accordingly, RAMV of MCI would be less than 1.00. In P. cristata the magnitude of sexual dimorphism for MCl-2 is less than that for MC3-5 (Table 2) . Similarly, the expectations are that AMV for MCl-2 would be less than that for MC3-5, and RAMVofMCI would be less than 1.00. However, the results show that C. guereza and P. cristata have the second (1.47) and third (1.41) highest RAMV of MC 1 among the species in this study (Table 6 ). Consequently, the high RAMV of MC 1 in C. guereza and P. cristata is not an artifact of sample composition.

This study cannot evaluate quantitatively the effect on RAMV of inters ample differences in geographic location of the specimens (i.e., whether the specimens were obtained from a single population or from multiple populations). However, with the exception of MTI in C. aethiops males, wildcaught and captive specimens are similar in proportionate metapodial length. The reasonable inference is that different populations would also be similar in proportionate metapodial length.

Interspecific differences in sexual dimorphism also cannot explain the heterogeneity in RAMV of MPI and, specifically, the high RAMV of MCI in C. guereza, A. geoffroyi, P. rubicunda, and P. cristata. The magnitude of sexual dimor-phism in metapodiallength is positively correlated with AMV (Table 4) . This result was, in part, the reason for computing RAMV. As the sexes are similar in the proportionate lengths of their metapodials, an increase in AMV of one metapodial is accompanied by a corresponding increase in AMV of the other metapodials in a pooled-sex sample (see above). Consequently, RAMV should be independent of the magnitude of sexual dimorphism. To illustrate by example, A. geoffroyi and P. rubicunda have the highest (1.61) and fourth highest (1.34), respectively, RAMVof MCI among the species in this study (Table 6 ). Nevertheless, these species are monomorphic in the length of MC1; the sexual dimorphism is 0.007 for A. geoffroyi and 0.003 for P. rubicunda (Table 2) . As two examples of contrast, H. lar is also monomorphic in the length of MCI (sexual dimorphism is -0.006), yet its RAMVis low, 1.05. Conversely, C. aethiops is highly dimorphic in MCI (sexual dimorphism is 0.175), yet its RAMV (1.05) is also low and similar to that of H. lar.

Finally, captive C. guereza females have longer MC2 and MC4-5 when compared with wild-caught females. When both types of females are combined in the pooled-sex sample, the expected results would be: (1) an increase in AMVof MC2 and MC4-5 relative to MCI and MC3; and (2) RAMV of MCI less than 1.00. However, C. guereza has the second highest RAMV in this study, 1.47 (Table 6 ). Therefore, differences between the sexes or between wild-caught and captive specimens in absolute metapodial length do not explain the interspecific heterogeneity in RAMV.

Mensuration error.-Among anthropoids, the relative variability of MPI is inversely associated with its relative length (rs = -0.55, see Results). Other researchers have noted an inverse relationship between size and variability of a structure (Bader and Hall 1959; Yablokov 1974; Rohlf et al. 1983) .

However, the present study shows that increased variability is not a correlate of decreased length alone (Table 3) . Rather, the inverse relationship between length and variability is exhibited by MPI in relation to MP2-5. Jouffroy et al. (1993; also see Rohlf et al. 1983) suggested the reason that shorter bones are more variable in length than longer bones is that the relative accuracy in mensuration is higher for longer bones. Therefore, the relationship between length and variability can be an artifact of mensuration error. This explanation, however, does not account for the results of the present study. Rohlf et al. (1983, p. 195) stated that "the way to avoid this problem (i.e., inverse relationship between the mean and its variance) ... is to measure the small features with the same relative level of precision as that used on the larger structure." In this study, there is a high level of precision in measuring metapodiallength (see Measurements). The relative level of precision for MC1, which is the shortest metapodial in P. cynocephalus, is 0.04%. This level of precision is less than or equal to that for four other metapodials (MC4, MT1, MT3, and MT5), and these latter four metapodials are an average of 66% longer than MC1. Therefore, mensuration error does not explain the inverse relationship between relative length and relative variability of MP1. Rather, developmental biology and evolutionary theory better explain this relationship and, more generally, the other results of this study.

In mammals, the blastemata for the digits of the hand and foot develop in a posterior-to-anterior sequence, with the blastema for digit one being the last to form (Forsthoefel 1963; Milaire 1965; Yasuda 1975; Shubin and Alberch 1986) . This posterior-to-anterior sequence of digital formation also characterizes birds, reptiles, and anurans (Shubin and Alberch 1986) . Experimental studies have demonstrated that a characteristic pattern of phalangeal and digital loss results from a general reduction in the amount of mesenchyme in the limb bud. For example, in Xenopus experimental reduction in mesenchymal volume results in the distal phalanx of the first digit being the most frequent bone lost, and the first digit being the most frequent digit lost (Alberch and Gale 1983, 1985; Shubin and Alberch 1986) .
body_text.section: Length and Variability of MPl: Developmental Biology and Evolutionary Theory

body_text.text: The reason for the preferential loss of the distal phalanx of the first digit may be that phalangeal development results from segmentation of the digital blastema (Shubin and Alberch 1986) . If the blastema for digit one is small, there may be insufficient mesenchyme to produce a blastema for the distal phalanx. Therefore, loss of the distal pollical phalanx in C. guereza and A. geoffroyi may be a consequence of a general reduction in the amount of mesenchyme allocated to the first digit. However, there are alternative mechanisms for phalangeal loss, as an element can be suppressed at anyone of several stages of development, including blastemal formation, chondrification, and skeletogenesis (Hinchliffe and Johnson 1980) ; vestigial structures may develop to various stages before regressing (Prentiss 1906; Lande 1978; Raynaud 1985; Van der Merwe 1985b) . Therefore, there may be different developmental pathways in C. guereza and A. geoffroyi for the shared morphology of a vestigial pollex (e.g., see Alberch and Gale 1985; Oster et al. 1988) . Unfortunately, the few observations on early pollical development in Colobus and Ateles do not resolve this issue (Schultz 1924; Jouffroy and Lessertisseur 1977) .
body_text.section: Length and Variability of MPl: Developmental Biology and Evolutionary Theory

body_text.text: Among anthropoids, P. pygmaeus is unique in showing structural reduction of the hallux. Approximately 59% of specimens do not have the distal hallucal phalanx (Schultz 1941; Tuttle and Rogers 1966) , but this structural reduction is sexually dimorphic. Phalangeal loss is seen in 87% of females, but only 33% of males (Tuttle and Rogers 1966) . The explanation for the sexual dimorphism in phalangeal loss may be a sexual difference in size of the hindlimb bud. Alberch (1985) has argued that variation in absolute limb bud size may explain intraspecific variation in digital number. He suggested that there are threshold values of limb bud size that are necessary for the specification of certain digits. This suggestion is consistent with the sexual dimorphism in newborn body mass for P. pygmaeus, in which males are approximately 20% larger than females (Hays sen et al. 1993) .
body_text.section: Length and Variability of MPl: Developmental Biology and Evolutionary Theory

body_text.text: A hypothetical and simplistic example may illustrate the basis for the inverse relationship seen in this study between the relative length of MPI and its relative variability. Assume that MC2-5 ordinarily have a blastemal length of 100 units each, and compare two situations: the blastema for MCI has a length of (a) 50 units or (b) 100 units. During cell recruitment in blastemal formation, if each blastema for MC2-5 "competitively acquires" up to five additional units of the mesenchyme that are normally allocated to MC1, then the range of variation in MCI is 30-50 units for situation (a) and 80-100 units for situation (b); the range for each MC2-5 would be 100-105. Situation (a) will have a higher AMV and RAMV for MCI than situation (b) as a result of the difference in length of their MCls. Consequently, an increase in relative variability accompanies structural reduction.
body_text.section: Length and Variability of MPl: Developmental Biology and Evolutionary Theory

body_text.text: Evolutionary theory also explains the inverse relationship between relative length and relative variability of MPI. Phenotypic variability is inversely associated with the intensity of stabilizing selection (Schmalhausen 1949; Yablokov 1974; Johnson 1976; Endler 1986; Mettler et al. 1988 ) and, perhaps, directional selection (Bader 1955; Johnson 1976; Lande and Arnold 1983 ; but see Guthrie 1965; Yablokov 1974) . Consequently, MPI that is relatively short will also be relatively highly variable if the disparity in length is due to selection for elongation of MP2-5, as opposed to selection for a short MPI.
body_text.section: Length and Variability of MPl: Developmental Biology and Evolutionary Theory

body_text.text: In summary, this study demonstrates quantitatively that: (1) a nonfunctional, vestigial MC 1 is both highly variable and poorly correlated in its length relative to MC2-5, and (2) relative length of MPI is a significant correlate of its relative variability. These results are in accord with evolutionary theory.
body_text.section: Length and Variability of MPl: Developmental Biology and Evolutionary Theory
